message.content: Yes, in the Appendix section of the paper (section A.2), the authors discussed the consent issue while using the datasets for their experiments. They mentioned that they do not conduct an independent investigation of consent beyond the considerations made by the authors who released the original datasets. The authors also manually verified that no humans were present in the archives curated by ReCo when using the LAION-5B dataset for qualitative studies.

Yes, the authors discuss the issue of consent in the appendix section, specifically in Appendix A.2, "Discussion of consent in used datasets." They mention that they work primarily with widely used computer vision benchmarks, and they do not conduct an independent investigation of consent beyond the considerations of the authors that released these datasets. For their exploratory studies using the LAION-5B dataset, they manually verified that no humans were present in the archives curated by ReCo. This indicates that they have taken steps to address the issue of consent and have provided a brief discussion on the matter in their paper.

Yes, the authors discuss the issue of consent in the Appendix section A.2. They primarily use widely-used computer vision benchmarks and do not conduct independent investigations of consent beyond the considerations of the authors who released these datasets. They ensure that no personally identifiable information or harmful content is present in the archives curated by ReCo, particularly while working with the LAION-5B dataset.
